awd_titl_txt: Partial Support for the Core Activities of the Committee on National Statistics
awd_abstract_narration:
Relevant, objective, high-quality, timely, and accessible information produced by federal statistical agencies is critical for informing decisions by policy makers for federal, state, and local governments as well as by private businesses and households. This project will provide partial support for the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine Committee on National Statistics (CNSTAT).  The Committee was established as a standing committee in 1972 and works to improve the statistical methods and measures produced by the diverse array of statistical agencies spread across the federal government and to help those agencies collaborate with each other to serve the public good. CNSTAT also contributes to improving the data that are available for economic and social science research applied to important national needs, such as understanding the economy, technology and innovation, public health, education, welfare, and other areas. CNSTAT conducts much of its work through consensus studies carried out by panels of volunteer experts, which review specific statistical programs and measures. It also conducts workshops and public seminars for the benefit of the statistical and research community and updates every 4 years a volume titled "Principles and Practices for a Federal Statistical Agency," which helps protect the objectivity and credibility of federal statistics.

Interacting with the federal statistical and research agencies and the social and economic sciences research community, CNSTAT will identify priority topics for study involving federal statistics and statistical methods.  For example, CNSTAT studies will help the Census Bureau design an accurate and cost-effective 2020 census and improve other nationally important surveys of households and businesses; help the National Center for Science and Engineering Statistics at NSF improve surveys of the science and engineering workforce and measures of innovation; and help the Department of Health and Human Services improve data on the elderly and disadvantaged people. An important ongoing initiative is to foster standards and methods for using multiple data sources to improve federal statistics by drawing on data from administrative records and from selected Internet and other non-traditional data sources in addition to the surveys currently used. The use of multiple data sources is imperative to hold down costs of federal statistical programs, improve data quality and timeliness, and maintain relevance and credibility in an era in which people are less likely to respond to surveys and there are competing statistics from non-government sources.

por.por_cntn:
The Committee on National Statistics (CNSTAT) was established in 1972 at the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine to improve the statistical methods and information on which public policy decisions are based. CNSTAT serves to strengthen the development of useful, accessible data and state-of-the-art analytic methods for research and policy analysis in the social, behavioral, and economic sciences and fills a critical gap as an integrative force for a highly decentralized federal statistical system. Its studies, workshops, and other activities address needed improvements in data and methods for understanding the economy, families and communities, public health, crime, education, immigration, poverty and welfare, and many other topics of importance for research and policy planning, monitoring, and evaluation. CNSTAT’s core activities and events support the federal statistical community by addressing cross-cutting issues and providing opportunities for professional and intellectual engagement. 

Intellectual Impact

Over the course of this grant, CNSTAT led or collaborated on dozens of studies that advance knowledge in the social sciences and related statistical and survey methods. CNSTAT released multiple reports about modernizing economic measurement, including An Updated Measure of Poverty, Modernizing the Consumer Price Index for the 21st Century, Creating an Integrated System of Data and Statistics on Household Income, Consumption, and Wealth, and A Roadmap to Reducing Child Poverty. CNSTAT also released reports or workshop proceedings related to improving the decennial census, such as Assessing the 2020 Census, 2020 Census Data Products: Demographic and Housing Characteristics File, and 2020 Census Data Products: Data Needs and Privacy Considerations.

CNSTAT published studies addressing how to make data available to researchers and policymakers while protecting the confidentiality of survey respondents, for example, A Roadmap for Disclosure Avoidance in the Survey of Income and Program Participation, Toward a 21st Century National Data Infrastructure: Managing Privacy and Confidentiality Risks with Blended Data and Innovations in Federal Statistics: Combining Data Sources While Protecting Privacy. CNSTAT also completed its three-report data infrastructure series, Toward a 21st Century National Data Infrastructure, which provides a vision for a new national data infrastructure for mobilizing and combining all relevant data resources to support social and economic research, policymaking, and other common good purposes. CNSTAT released multiple reports over the course of the grant covering data infrastructure in specific social domains, including Improving Data Collection and Measurement of Complex Farms, Building Data Capacity for Patient-Centered Outcomes Research, A Vision and Roadmap for Education Statistics, and Measuring Law Enforcement Suicide.

CNSTAT also contributed to advancing knowledge outside of the social sciences, for example, An Assessment of Native Seed Needs and the Capacity for Their Supply, which examines the needs for native plant restoration. CNSTAT also contributed to general scientific issues in the report, Reproducibility and Replicability in Science, which assesses the extent of issues related to reproducibility and replicability and offers recommendations for improving rigor and transparency in scientific research.

Broader Impacts

In addition to advancing the social and statistical sciences, CNSTAT seeks to support the statistical community itself, as well as increase public understanding of federal statistics. CNSTAT holds at least two public seminars per year and large public events to engage the federal statistical system and related professionals. Examples of public seminars include “Modernizing Poverty Measurement” (2023), “Managing Privacy and Confidentiality Risks with Blended Data” (2024), “International Approaches to Conducting a Census in the 21st Century” (2023), “Measuring Sex, Gender Identity, and Sexual Orientation” (2022), and “Leveraging and Integrating Data for Disasters” (2018). Large events have included a workshop on Challenges and New Approaches for Protecting Privacy in Federal Statistical Programs (2019), Big Data Day (2018), Data Linkage Day (2019), and AI Day for Federal Statistics (2024). The latter events featured a keynote address, panel discussions, paper presentations, and posters highlighting the work of federal agencies. These large events provided an opportunity for networking and professional development for early- and mid-career agency staff. 

In 2017 and 2021, CNSTAT released the 6th and 7th editions of Principles and Practices for a Federal Statistical Agency (P&P), CNSTAT’s influential report highlighting the public good provided by strong federal statistical agencies. It provides a code of ethics that underlies statistical agencies’ shared culture and missions. CNSTAT provided, upon request, dozens of briefings on P&P to agency staff as a form of training, interagency councils (e.g., Chief Data Officer Council, Evaluation Office Council), and Cabinet Department officials. P&P was cited in statistical agency head confirmation hearings and in a Government Accountability Office report (2023).

Finally, CNSTAT developed a video "Trustworthy data for the common good" to educate the public about the value of the federal statistical system to the nation. CNSTAT developed interactive webpages for many reports in order to make them more accessible to the public, such as for P&P and Measuring Law Enforcement Suicide.

All CNSTAT reports, interactive sites, and other resources are available for free at https://www.nationalacademies.org/cnstat/.
